newsitem.title: USA: Sonoco Brazilian consolidation going slower.
newsitem.headline: Sonoco Brazilian consolidation going slower.

text.p: Sonoco Products Co said on Wednesday that it was on track to meet its earnings goal of $250 million by the year 2000, but that the consolidation of its Brazilian operations was going slower than expected.
While Sonoco said it was optimistic for the long-term prospects in Brazil, it said the general economy there remained soft.

The company, which announced flat fully-diluted third quarter 1996 earnings of $0.41 per share, said earnings were hurt by costs due to Sonoco's recent initiatives, including closing seven paper converting plants and expanding 20 others.
Sonoco said it expected positive contributions from these initiatives starting in the fourth quarter 1995.
Internationally, Sonoco said its third quarter was also hurt by the cost of upgrading a recently acquired paper mill in Shanghai, China.

In the consumer packaging unit, the company said it was continuing to integrate and consolidate its label business. Costs associated with this consolidation included a plant closing, severance costs, and inefficiencies resulting from transferring volume among plants.
The company also said it continued to have costs related to installing and starting two new rotogravure presses in its flexible packaging operations and a new press at the carton unit.
But Sonoco said it was on track to double sales and earnings from its 1994 base by the year 2000.

Chairman and Chief Executive Officer C.W. Coker said, "Sonoco's plans for achieving these goals include four key drivers -- globalization of Sonoco's technology, increases in productivity, growth of our U.S. businesses and the continued building of a strong team around a solid culture and value structure."
